name: Jacobson's conjecture
rephrased: In a Noetherian ring, the intersection of all powers of its Jacobson radical is the zero ring (the trivial ring).
implication_form: It is not possible to rewrite the conjecture in the form "If P, then Q" because no formal statement was provided.
explained: Jacobson's conjecture states that for a two-sided Noetherian ring R, the intersection of all powers of its Jacobson radical (the set of all quasi-regular elements, denoted J(R)) is the zero ideal. In other words, ∩_{n=1}^∞ J(R)^n = (0). This means that every element in the intersection must be nilpotent (i.e., some positive integer power of it is zero). The conjecture relies critically on the ring being two-sided Noetherian (both left and right Noetherian).
